If you loved the first season of Kimi ni Todoke like I did, you may also feel as betrayed by season two as I do. The writing quality changed so drastically between seasons one and two that I was unsure whether or not I was even watching the same show. Bad news; I was.
The first season of KnT was pretty darn good. It had tons of heart, great characters in Sawako, Chizuru, Ayane, Kurumi, and the rest. The comedic elements were solid, if not occasionally timed awkwardly, and up until the very end, I was invested 100%.
Then comes season two. Instead of the story flowingalong smoothly like it did in S1, S2 immediately time skips again and again, right from the get-go. Ayane said in S1, "love is all about timing". Well, the story lost its sense of time, and not just in a narrative sense. The story beats and comedic timing also suffered greatly in this poor follow-up to a pretty good first run.


The biggest sin of KnT's second season, though, is how they erased 25 episodes of character development with the aforementioned time skips and some pretty insane contrived drama. I can't remember a time I've been more frustrated with a romantic comedy story's tropes and cliches than in this 12 episode run.


Seriously, they pulled out all the stops here. It's almost impressive. Not to say that S1 didn't have its fair share of romance story cliches either, but it at least used them within the walls of its cohesive narrative filled with likable characters.


The art maintains most of the first season's quality, and the sound design is alright. The voice acting remained solid, too.


Overall, this second season was incredibly frustrating to watch. It's a very jarring difference when compared to the great first season. In my opinion, skipping the drama and having Sawako and Kazehaya get together in a 26th episode in the first season, followed by a second season of further character development with the two in a relationship, as well as further developing the other characters around them (poor Ryuu x Chizuru pairing got almost zero attention) would have been a far, far better and more compelling second story.


tl;dr A very disappointing and frustrating 2/10.

To put it bluntly, it's very difficult for me to name any other romance anime that isn't ecchi or based entirely on sexual feelings. Kimi ni Todoke takes a far more pure approach. 
I think these are some of Kimi ni Todoke's best points:
[+] Both characters are already in love with each other; the other isn't being forced.
[+] The characters feel happy just seeing each other smile; their love is pure.
[+] Sawako dressesmodestly, has natural looking hair, and is pretty much flat-chested; she is not fanservice.\n\n
Some complain about the slow progression and misunderstandings, but I think it adds suspense and makes this worth watching. What'd be the point if they got together right off the bat? This season was more focused on Sawako and Kazehaya overcoming their own personal obstacles, which I think was more interesting and made for a more acceptable ending.\n\n

[x] Sawako turning chibi regularly was pretty unsightly and not funny. I think this anime would've looked a lot better without the chibi parts. \n

[x] There was a lack of animation in many parts, substituted with an abundance of pentagon-shaped bubbles floating everywhere.\n\n
I liked Kimi ni Todoke for its simple/realistic character design, character development, pretty good love story, and its occasional funny parts. It was just all around good to me while, thankfully, avoiding most of anime's typical shortcomings.

A measure of a good romance anime is when the adaption entices you to read the original source. It should make you feel that you can experience the emotion yourself. And, no matter how impossible it is, it should always give you hope that the same thing might happen to you in real life. Kimi ni Todoke (KnT from here on out) satisfies all criteria well, but not without making you want to punch something midway. Keep in mind that this review is only for the second season, covering just 12 episodes. Most of the themes and styles from the first season are carried overthough, so this reviewer will try to point out just the elements that stand out. 


Story/Character: 10


Lights, sound and art might make an anime shine and sparkle (there’s plenty of that as well, so we’ll talk more about that later) but the story is what keeps you from dropping the show. And when you consider that KnT is a spin on the usual “boy-meets-girl” scenario, it does very well to make itself stand out from the already crowded pack. KnT also does well to avoid any cliché events, so there is no beach/onsen/fanservice scene that most anime show these days.  


 Most of the development for the other characters were back in season one, this time around the focus in solely on the two main characters, Kuronuma Sawako and Kazehaya Shouta. It showed how they slowly figured out their feelings for each other and finally (and I do mean FINALLY) got together as a couple. There were a lot of times when I found myself actually shouting at the TV, frustrated by the madness that was going on with these two. Nevertheless, it was great seeing how Sawako changed from the first season. They managed to tie up all the loose ends, even the one with another character, Kurumizawa Ume. In some way, a character or two will endear him or herself with you.


Art/Sound: 9


If you could pardon the reference, the world of KnT was simply “shining, shimmering, splendid”. There were so much color and so much sparkle (or what I call “bokeh”) that it would make a good piece in an art exhibit. Though it might feel over the top sometimes, the art does help portray and intensify the emotion or action being showed. Nothing feels out of place, from the “bokeh” of Sawako’s smile to the chibi-fied and simplified versions of the characters to show comedic appeal. Quality is the key word here and the studio, Production I.G., didn’t skimp out on eye-candy as far as I can see. 


As for the sound, the majority of the music from KnT is piano and violin ensembles which fit the overall feel of the show. Just like with the art, not one note felt out of place. For comedic scenes, the BGM would usually be something quirky and funky to make you laugh out loud. And for romantic scenes, the music would be enough for you to shed a manly tear or two (or womanly tear, for the ladies out there). Overall, both the art and the music meshed together to help deliver the story the best way possible. And it has surely done its part well. 


Overall: 9


As with any second season, it is recommended that you watch the first season first (duh~) unless you want to feel out of place with the story. That being said, Kimi ni Todoke is certainly an anime worthy of anyone’s Top 10. It shows us love, makes us love [the characters] and let us feel love in return. True to its name, this anime absolutely reaches out to us.

And so the magical love story continues…….
After seemingly a very long wait the sequel is here!
There’s a long review coming!
ABOUT THE STORY
In this sequel Sawako already managed to really have friends naturally. She even became so popular that it seemed people was fearing and worshipping her like a God. With her hard work and helped from friends, she became more sociable. And of course, the much awaited love story of Sawako and Kazehaya was the main plot in this series. With the appearance of a new character and somewhat a third party between them, their relationship gotten so complicated at first but with the adviceand helped behind the scenes from their friends they finally expressed what they truly felt and at the end they managed to be together.


Again! This story never ceases to move me! This is the best love story in the history of anime. This sequel was even more amazing than the previous one, not that I don’t love the season one. It was irritating at the beginning but the ending was so damn worth it. The story was simple and light yet it was so amazing. I am already fed up with love stories with characters just confessing then going out then kisses then going all the way then getting married in the end. It is so cliché and over used. In this series, the love story is very much elaborated so you will really feel the romance of it; from the small gestures of affection to the overwhelming feelings. That amazing feeling and happiness from just looking at him then the embarrassing feeling when he/she caught you staring at him/her. The nerve-wracking sensation when he’s/she’s coming then the heart-pounding feeling when he’s/she’s close to you. And the excitement and nervous feeling of finally confessing and of course, the most magnificent feeling of realizing that it is mutual. We sometimes forget that those small gestures are what make the first stage of falling in love the most wonderful part of the whole experience.  It is almost like a sin how the author managed to create such master piece.


ABOUT THE CHARACTERS

The characters were more amazing because the main plot showed each and everyone’s real personality and how it affected each character. The appearance of somewhat playboy third party influenced the flow of the story. Though it was mainly for Kazehaya because he was so jealous of Miura and feared for the first time of the possibility that someone might fall for Sawako, too. At first, Miura was so irritating for butting in between the two but he showed his significance later on. Even though not directly, their friends was so reliable and helpful to them for advising and making them realize their feelings for each other. Especially Pin, who was magnificently and hilariously giving them encouraging words. He even bragged about it himself. It was so hilarious that he always appeared at the right time and moment for Sawako and Kazehaya. He can really give important advice in his own very unique way. In fact, he was the main source of encouraging words for Kazehaya.


ABOUT KAZEHAYA AND SAWAKO

 Of course, let’s not forget the two love birds! In the beginning both of them were so damn irritating but most of the time funny. Both had to realize what they really felt. For Sawako, she had to make up her mind if what she really felt for Kazehaya were mere admiration or genuine love. For Kazehaya, he had to really understand that it was truly possible that Sawako might felt the same feelings for him, too, and not just simple admiration. Oh! I also really loved whenever Kazehaya got jealous because he was so cute, well, most guys get really cute when they’re jealous. They struggled a lot because both of them were so dense that they didn’t even realize that what they felt was the same. They ended up saying harsh words to each other without even realizing it when the truth was the opposite of what they were saying. Well, at the end they managed to truly express what they felt and FINALLY they reached each other’s feelings.  Like what the significance of the title “KIMI NI TODOKE”! In the very first episode of season one, Kazehaya wondered if his feelings will reach Sawako and now, in this sequel, his feelings finally reached her. After so many complications, at last they were finally together. I am genuinely so happy for them. It even feels like they are real-life friends of mine and I am rooting for them so bad. That’s how much I am moved by this series!


ABOUT THE ANIMATION and SOUND

The animation was still superb. Every episode was magically made. There was no episode that was not worth watching. The dialogues of every character genuinely moved me. The characters was so beautifully made that it literally blew me away from my seat. I’ve never seen such gorgeous looking couple in any anime for so many years. With the great voice talent of the seiyus, every line was so captivating. The lines were sincerely delivered because of them. Every hug, every touch, and every word genuinely showed how much the two characters loved each other. To sum it up, the soundtracks made the whole experience unforgettable. 


For so many years, Lovely Complex has never been replaced in its spot for my number one love story but it would be a sin to not put Kimi ni Todoke in the first slot. This series genuinely moved me and gave me something precious to remember for the rest of my life. This series is one of the very few animes which I am dying to see for a continual airing like my favorites; Naruto: Shippuden, Bleach and One piece. I am just so sad finishing it. SO SAD!  I was begging for more!  I just want more of them! I just want to continue witnessing their love story! I literally fall in love with this master piece!

"I finally...reached you!" 
The second season of Kimi ni Todoke can be summed up in this sentence. Yes, I know this is probably a spoiler, but it's not like you didn't know it was going to happen. The twelve episodes continue right were the first season left off, our main couple continues its sloooow but unbelievably sweet path to romance...encountering a great deal of misunderstandings and situations that made me at times facepalm myself, these guys are so naive. Yet, I didn't find those moments overwhelming, because it's all part of the ride. I found the second season very satisfactory, truly, the interactions between Kazehayaand Sawako were so beautiful and heartfelt, a kiss wasn't really needed. I haven't encountered another romantic anime that made me feel that way.

Considering that it took 26 episodes in the first season for Sawako to finally hold the hand of the boy she liked, I was doubtful that a 13-episode second season could really make any progress if it held to the same pacing as the first season. 
I was dismayed to see the route that was taken in the second season. After reaching a relative pinnacle of closeness in their relationship at the end of the first season, the second season seems intent on back-pedalling, stalling, and otherwise dismantling all the progress they've made up to that point. The inclusion of new characters and rivals wasto be expected, but it reaches a point where it seems everyone in the school is set on sabotaging or supporting the two main character's relationship. The reasons or excuses keeping Sawako and Kazehaya apart become increasingly absurd and implausible; in the penultimate incident, their relationship is effectively killed by a nuance in conversation so subtle that Western audiences may not even catch it. \n
Kimi ni Todoke second season carries on the warmth and amusing insight of the first, but the strategic efforts of the author to prolong the courtship are too effective, making this story arc more grueling and unhappy. Even if the audience is committed to these characters by now, the second season may exhaust their patience.
